Simple answer is F=m.a,
Force = mass x acceleration.
Imagine the mass of elephant is 1000 kg, dog is 10kg and rat 1kg. In a free fall drop on earth is approximately 9.8m/s.
So, force on each body is different.
Force on elephant body is = 1000x9.8 = 9800 Newton.
Force on dog body is = 98 Newton.
Force on mouse body is = 9.8 Newton.

Greater the force on body more damage. So the Elephant is will take more damage.
Consider ant falling, imagine mass of ant is 0.001 that means the force on ant body upon Impact will be 0.001x9.8 = 0.0098 Newton.

Density is just as important, if not more so than density. This is why birds can grow to pretty large sizes while still maintaining their ability to fly.
Insects have a lower than expected density because even though chitin is generally denser than flesh, insects also contain plenty of empty space because they don't have lungs and instead rely on a large network of empty tubes and sacs to move air around.

Thank the Lord (well… Evolution) for these evolving insects & their incredible features!

Shellac flakes are made from a Beatle like bug called the “lac bug”… it’s a small secretion left behind that we have used for thousands of years as a finish for wood and other materials. Along well a million other uses…. like makeup!

I use it almost every day…. building custom guitars and violins.(and for countless other woodworking and random tasks.)
And you can buy genuine shellac flakes at most home-improvement stores now! Which is a new thing… Used to only be available by special order.

In my opinion… No man-made material makes a better finish than what we thankfully get from nature!

Size has a big influence here but i think a more accurate description is speed. Which is directly influenced by surface area. The mouse has a much larger surface area compared to it's weight which means it's terminal velocity (the maximum speed it can reach while falling) is much smaller. The mouse doesn't have enough weight to counteract the resistance it encounters pushing it's way through the air. Consequently the bonds in its cells have with one another and the ability of it's bones to resist breaking are enough to counteract the impact from it's speed while falling. The force of the impact being greatly influenced by the mass of the mouse and the speed at which it is falling.

If the elephant and the wolf shared the same ratio of surface area to mass. They would fall at roughly the same speed.

Think of it like this. You fall out of a plane and you'll have roughly a set terminal velocity. Now you add a parachute. Well according to this video your size has increased so you should fall faster. You might until you pull the cord and release the parachute but releasing the parachute greatly increases the surface area of your mass. The amount of air you have to displace as you fall rises and your speed falls. You land safely thanks not to your size but the air you had to move to descend.

I really like Kurzgesagt content, but the statement at 1:28 is PLAIN WRONG. That is not true. Neither size or mass determine how big the effect of gravity (which in this context means speed in free fall, I suppose) is. The mass of an object determines the FORCE, and the size impacts the AIR RESISTANCE that counteracts the force of gravity. So one could say that the density of the object (but also its shape) determine the terminal velocity. Also - the effect at 2:13 is rather minor compared to the terminal velocity when it comes to surviving free fals. Because when bugs hit the windscreen of my car, traveling at 180km/h, they spread on a big chunck of it quite spectaculary too. And their small size doesn’t help them much.

Before I watch the video, let me test what I already know.

More mass means more force. They are affected with the same force of gravity which is 9.81 m/s.

Rat: F=ma
Dog: 2F=2ma (because the dog is heavier compared to the rat.)
Elephant: 3F=3ma (because the elephant is heavier compared to the dog.)
The bigger mass you have, the more gravity you got
So size does matter...

Mass is the key factor here, not size. Whilst in the animal kingdom the mass of the animal usually increses with it's size it's misleading at best to argue that the volume of an object (it's size) has anything to do with how much kinetic energy is released during impact. It's all mass. And infact a smaller object with the same mass as a larger object will carry more kinetic energy at impact due to less air resistance - making this video even more misleading.

Something is terribly wrong with this video.Volume doesn't determine mass until you assume all the animals are made up of the same material (with the same density). Whether it shatters or not depends on the objects capacity to absorb the impact energy without permanent damage(proof resilience) and also on the collision (rebound energy).Higher the energy with which the object rebounds, lower its damage. This is why jumping on trampoline hurts less than on concrete. Using enough cushion, even elephants can be landed safely.

I’m sorry but their math on the ratio of an animals surface area relative to its volume does not increase as you increase the size of an animal. That would be like saying the ratio of a side of a cube increases relative to a cubes volume. If you saw a photo of a cube with no context to its size it still has the same relationship between its sides and its volume regardless of how big it is. Like yes a cube that has side length of 1m has a volume of 1m cubed. And a cube that has side length 1,000m has a volume of 1,000,000,000m. But it also has a side length of 1km and a volume of 1km^3. Its built into the units. That 1m box also has a side length of 1,000mm and 1,000,000,000 mm^3. The ratio you get is just based off of what units you use and doesn’t reflect the actual relationship between the sides. The important relationship is side length to side length cubed and that never changes

Actually, it can be understood easier by 2 formulas. (mg) which is gravity times mass which gives us the force of gravity (Fg). Fg=mg As we incrase the mass, force incrases.
Second formula is momentum. P=mv. Momentum is basicly how strong is an object according to its mass and velocity. When we release an object from the top of a building, a mountain or something higher than sea level, its potential energy turns into the kinetic energy, which is 1/2 m v squared. So from the formula, we can understand that it has a velocity now and it incrases over time. According to the momentum formula, velocity increases. However, it still depends on the mass. That is why very little animals and insects dont die from falling, yet bigger animals die. Engineer speaking.

FNet=ma=mg (net force=mass x acceleration = mass x gravity). Acceleration is gravity=9.8m/s^2.

It depends on the thickness of the mattress too. In your philosophy, there is 2 variables and 1 constant. And 2 variables will not end up with a right conclusion.

Variable 1: Size & Weight of the animals (Which is what you are trying to find out)
Variable 2: Mattress thickness/Size & weight proportion (Which is what you have missed out)
Constant: Total height of falling.

To be fair for all 3 animals, the mattress thickness/size & Weight shall be Equal, then their results "might" ended the same.

--------------------
Lastly, friction do play important role in this philosophy.
If all of them are falling in vacuum, whatever size & weight you were mentioning will end up exploding like that giant elephant. :)

The effects of the fall really all comes down to the mass and the speed.
Multiply those 2 factors together and you have the "Momentum". The higher the momentum, the greater the boom you make when you land.
 
Q = m * v
Q: Momentum
m: Mass
v: speed

Now it's true that the the larger the surface of an object, the slower it will fall, thanks to friction with air.
However, in the case presented on the video, air friction has little effect.

If you drop a dog an elephant and a mouse from a building they'll fall at approximately the same speed. Sure surface will change it a bit, but it's not the greatest factor in the equation.
The real deal is mass here, that's the main thing that changes the Momentum, and the main thing that varies drastically between the three subjects.

When you fall and hit the ground, the normal force reacts equally with the force you exerted upon impact. Equation F=ma tells us that the larger the falling object’s mass, the greater the force exerted. The larger the size, the larger the volume, the larger the mass, the larger the force. That is why an elephant will die upon falling at a tall height (Distance is also crucial, of course).

Another thing to consider when dealing with larger sizes as well is that life, regardless of size, always starts at the smallest level and evolves a way to move from one order of magnitude of size (say, the single cell level to something the size of a mite, and so forth).  In fact, one of the reasons why the largest sea creatures are mammals (I'm talking about you, whales) is because there are two techniques most mammals have:  Viviparous birth, which allows for birthing larger young than laying eggs, and lactation, a convenient way for babies to use the size and nutritional reserves of Mom to grow further.  With this, huge creatures can focus their survival fitness mostly on their own order of magnitude rather than all the ones below them.

The only reason an elephant cannot be a as small as an ameba is because we define creatures 100% by appearance. If something doesn't look like an elephant it isn't one in the human mind. An elephant over the course of a million years could evolve to the size of an ameba, but In doing so it would lose all its recognisable features that it make it an elephant. That is because being smaller it wouldn't need the features it already has, it would need different ones based on its new surroundings and problems. Hypothetically and elephant could become the size of a pea but because it would look so different we wouldn't consider it as an elephant

Size is another overlooked argument against evolution. There's no evolutionary need for life to grow in size as is supposed to have happened; increasing size makes it difficult to survive. The most sustainable size is something at the bacterial level. An insect size is basically the max size anything would need to get since they reach terminal velocity almost instantly and thus can never be killed by falling. Anything that can die simply from falling down is at an evolutionary disadvantage. Gravity is a universal environmental pressure that over millions of years would have wiped the planet clean of every organism that could die from just falling down.

"Size" is the same reason we don't have gigantic humans either. Scaling ourselves up past a certain height range, you start to run into a whole host of issues. Since volume increases so much in proportion to size, our bones wouldn't be strong enough for us to even stand. Not to mention our hearts would have great difficulty pumping blood, and even the weight of our organs could crush us. So all those superheroes with growing powers are truly fantasy.

The reason the elephant dies and the mouse does not is because gravity produces a force, and force = mass * acceleration. F=ma. The gravitational acceleration, a, is always constant on Earths surface so the only variable that changes the amount of force experienced is mass. A mouse has small amount of mass, therefore experiences a small amount of force. Elephant has larger mass, experiences a larger force and explodes.

I think that a lot of misconceptions about evolution come from the fact that it's often described as having some intention. For example, when a species survives a wide scale event thanks to a genetic mutation-as a result of evolution- people often describe it as an "evolutionary response" or behave as though there was some conscious force driving the mutation towards the best possible outcome. Really, evolutionary mutations are completely random. Whether or not a species survives depends on whether one member HAPPENS to develop a mutation that would allow it and its offspring to better survive. This is why a lot of...less scientific individuals can think that evolution is hokey, because they think the theory entails some kind of ultra convenient series of sequential, back to back changes. Let me say that I by NO means blame people for describing it as a kind of natural engineering, evolution, by its very nature, suggests that evolved species are almost statistically certain to be in some way superior to their predecessors, that's HOW the mutation endures in the first specimen and persists through multiple generations. Because so many mutations will happen over a long period of time, we only pay attention to the "evolved" traits, because they made a difference. As a result, people who aren't as educated on evolution think that it seems all too convenient.
I think the best explanation on the nature of evolution was given by Stephen Hawking on a show he had (I believe it was on PBS), where he had a group of people engage in an experiment involving blindfolds, a sort of clay, a catapult, and a castle tower. If I find it, I'll edit this comment to include the link so everybody can see it, it's well worth your time!
Also, if anybody is interested to continue this discussion or include their thoughts, I'd be glad to oblige you.

I love how evolution chanced upon an amazing and critical ability for insects (which would have taken an incredibly long time to evolve btw), and disregards all the prior insects without this ability that would have almost certainly died and likely become extinct.

It's a lot like the origins of male and female. Evolution apparently felt the need to make the existence of life more difficult by splitting an asexual organism into 2 genders male and female. Why? How?

How does splitting into genders help life succeed? How did evolution chance upon having both genders have organs and cells that successfully work together to procreate? Why would it make life more difficult to procreate? Evolution takes a LONG time, how is it possible both the male and female organism evolved at the same time and place to procreate?

I have no problem with micro-evolution. You see variations within species everywhere. But you can't use micro-evolution to prove macro-evolution, cross species evolution.

Evolution just seems to be an endless series of miracles. The probabilities of endlessly chancing upon these truly amazing "technologies" if you will, or abilities (look at that water beetle in the video) is so small I find it impossible to accept. It's not just one thing morphing into another, it's literally a brand new ability. Which is amazing. Humans envy that sort of design.

I've actually been quite curious about the 'size correlation to lifespan' of organisms. It seems to wildly vary, but I've always been curious about how some of the longest lived animals are moderately sized(tortoises), and how in, say dogs, it trends to 'smaller lives longer'. Obviously the very large breeds of dogs have issues with their bodies(If I recall most large breeds have heart issues generally. I'd love to know if that's a form of 'species-giganticism' compared to say a smaller breed). But I don't really hear much about the opposite end of the spectrum having downsides in optimum lifespan.  Medium sized dogs average around 10(a little above in a good household), but then smaller dogs can be ancient compared to their large breed cousins. I see so many Mastiff's, Danes, etc. peak at what could very well be only a third of the way through a small  Rat Terrier's life.

FWIW water not only has surface tension (which amounts to its preference to stick to itself rather than smear out) it also likes sticking to many other things, which is what makes it wet (mercury isn't wet for humans, doesn't leave moisture/liquid residue, because it doesn't like sticking to humans). That latter property is what makes water cling to you after submersion and it's what initially pulls bugs into droplets of water (that and the surface tension would then keep it there).

Speaking of scaling things up and down, we're aware that when we start to analyze things that are really small, like on the quantum level, physics gets weird. So if you imagine being some entity at the quantum level who understands those physics, that our Newtonian physics would seem weird, assuming they even have a means to observe it. Now imagine some scale that is larger than our observable universe, beyond anything we know how to observe. What if things at that scale operate on some crazy physics that we also can't comprehend, and to entities at that scale, our physics are as foreign as quantum physics are to us. Eventually, when you get large enough, our physics just don't make sense anymore. I'm not a physicist, and I don't know how plausible this idea is, but its something to think about. What if the scale of how big and how small things can be is actually infinite, and the limits of what we can understand is set by the limits of our understanding of physics, and likewise for any sentient entities that might exist at those scales.

im calling peta

Mass, and therefore weight, increases with size (assuming density remains constant). But the strength of the chemical bonds holding body tissues together, remains the same. So when an animal's size reaches a certain threshold, a fall from a considerable height produces a large enough impact force on the body to break the chemical bonds holding tissues together, thus injuring or killing the animal. If the animal is very small the impact force on the body is not sufficient to break those bonds so the animal escapes unharmed. So one way of looking at it is that the impact forces increase with size while the chemical bonds holding tissues together remain the same. Injury happens when the animal's size results in impact forces strong enough to break chemical bonds.

Or how falling on your head can kill you, but under right conditions, the human body could potentially withstand around 50 Gs of acceleration with no permanent damage.

Us humans are in that prefect balance between agile monkeys, and gentle giants. Big enough that we can chop down the trees that make our tools, and fuel our fires; but small enough that we can fit inside a small capsule, launch off Earth, and colonize the galaxy.

actually, the amount of mass a body has doesn't effect said body's gravitational acceleration. The more mass you have, the more inertia you have when you are moving. if the earth had no air resistance, everything would accelerate towards earth's center of mass at about 9.8 m/s per second because gravity pulls on each individual atom equally. the reason the elephant explodes upon impact with the ground while the mouse makes it out perfectly fine is because the mouse has very little inertia to begin with. once the mouse hits the mattresses, the mattresses can effectively transfer inertia away from the mouse gradually enough so that it does not experience fatal g-forces. On the other hand, the elephant has way too much inertia to be stopped gradually enough by the mattresses to save its life. the part of the elephant that hits the ground first was not designed to hold up 4-25x an elephant's weight. the g-forces experienced on impact is what makes the elephant feel 4-25x heavier. so when it makes impact, the bottom has nowhere to go except sideways as the rest of the elephant crushes down on it.

No disrespect intended.

Isn't mass irrelevant to a free falling object?
I mean the equation that gives us the speed after we fall a number of meters h, specifically, u=sqrt(2gh), doesn't take into account mass. So, mass is irrelevant, no?

EDIT: Oh yes, E=(1/2)*m*u^2 takes mass into consideration, the more mass you have, the more energy you have by the time you hit the bottom because
E=(1/2)*m*(sqrt(2gh))^2=(1/2)*m*2*g*h=mgh ah there it is

Without alterations to density, or perhaps buoyancy, making an object larger exponentially increases the amount of stress a falling object will experience on its surface of impact.

The reason a balloon can fall far slower when inflated is in part due to decreasing density that more approximates the surrounding air. Though it does gain some mass by having more air inside, with respect to the atmosphere around the mass is far more distributed. In the case of helium balloons, hot air balloons, and great blimps, while still effectively more massive than their deflated counterparts, their density is far less than that of air, allowing them to not just fall slower, but upward until they reach the low-density areas of the atmosphere.

Animals aren't like balloons, in that their volume tends to be filled and supported by solid mass. As their size increases, the amount of stress they experience on any part of their body becomes exponential. Ancient animals such as dinosaurs could reach greater sizes thanks to their hollowed out, air-tight bones, in addition to the greater oxygen content at their time. Whales can grow even larger, as the water they swim through helps support their weight, with air and fat keeping their bodies buoyant.

Even if an animal were to be more balloon-like regarding density, the sheer length of their bodies will cause a number of other changes. For one, signals from the brain to the body take longer. Blood must travel further to deliver oxygen. Increased volume will decrease heat dissipation. Assuming surface area to volume ratio remains consistent, just enough to allow them to overcome air resistance, the animal's metabolism and response time would decrease as a byproduct. They'd work effectively the same, but slower.

Why does a fly so easily evade your attempts to swat it? Though having a far smaller brain that would reduce its memory and data processing capacity, its reaction time is far faster. Its signals have far less length to move through, allowing for immediate response to stimuli. Of course, since it has mass and has to move through air, its reaction time won't be enough to overcome the difficulty of moving its mass through a resisting medium. Because you have greater length, in addition to mass that allows you to overcome air resistance, the ends of your arms will have greater potential velocity than the fly when swung. With your bare hands, and a well-timed strike, you can splatter a fly... though it'd be easier to just use a fly swatter.

A few problems with how this movie addresses this subject:

1. Physical laws are identical regardless of size. They are simply what they are. Yet, we barely understand them. Size matters because of non-linear change as a function of size of properties (of materials from which living beings are made of) and their structure (shortly correlation between mass -> density -> and surface area).

2. Another misconception: gravity has nearly the same effect regardless of size (at least when considering a range between an ant and an elephant - see how constant g=9.81 m/s is considered as rather constant on earth). What matters again is air drag, which is a function of surface area and air density mostly (bit more complicated than that, though it is fair simplification). Outcome of "falling" is a function of drag and mass.

Good luck with next episode!

To answer the next part of the video which will be coming about a month... is Temperature. Dinosaurs back then were cold-blooded (though some studies show some of them were once warm-blooded) and back then during the time of the dinosaurs, the atmosphere and global temperature was really really hot so they took advantage of this by evolving into massive creatures, because their bodies didn't need to worry about heating themselves to the right body temperature.

Plus, the amount of cells of an amoeba are too little that if they were theoretically scaled ten fold, their cells would burst and they would die instantly because it can't handle the surroundings it's in. And since the cells of an amoeba are just primary boring cells like the mitochondria and golgi apparatus and so on, they don't have specialized cells made to adapt to the type of environment a like elephant would have. they are small that those cells an elephant has are just nonessential to the tiny creature. They evolved that way so that they got what they needed.

This video is very misleading! Scientifically, everything falls at the same speed. They once threw a bowling ball and a feather from a tower and both fell at the same speed. And since an elephant can withstand many magnitudes of force more than a mouse (try hammering a mouse vs. an elephant) the elephant would live!
This is a well animated, but very misleading.

As a child, I reasoned that an organism's size might well affect it's perception of time. I still imagine that to ants, we titanic humans seem to move very slowly, which would also explain how flies react so quickly to would-be swatters. Not being an expert, I think it has to do with the distance and strength of signals needed to perceive and react, which would put small organisms at an advantage. But I wonder if an organisms size for neural traffic keyed by the laws of physics is what determines time-span perception, or something more (or else). We do know time dilation exist relative to mass (albeit noticeable difference happens only under extreme conditions). On the subject of free fall, if an ant has a lower terminal velocity relative to humans, and it experiences time slower, then perhaps an ant in free fall might experience a glide more than a fall.

I do have a basic understanding of why there are no giant insects anymore. Prehistoric dragonflies and scorpions were massive because the atmosphere was so full of oxygen. As time progresses more and more of he atmosphere was effected by flora fauna, volcanic activity, and animals, and it slowly lowered to the 21% we have today. Insect bodies aren't built to absorb oxygen as well as ours are, and as a consequence, they became smaller and smaller. Less volume=less oxygen needed.
